DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Panama Emphasis Shifting to `Humanitarian Concerns'

EDS: TOPS with 7 grafs to eliminate reference to Noriega surrendering, UPDATE with news agency report that papal nuncio saying he won't turn Noriega over to US authorities; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs bgng, `After the'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush had just returned from a Pentagon briefing on the situation in Panama on Christmas Eve when he learned that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had sought refuge from Vatican authorities. Bush had interrupted his holiday vacation to fly by helicopter from the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., for 90 minutes of briefings from Pentagon officials on Panama, and he had called Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of the U.S. Southern Command in Panama. At the time, he said he had no idea when U.S. troops might accomplish one of the key goals for their invasion of Panama early Wednesday, the capture of the deposed Panamanian dictator who is under U.S. indictment on drug-trafficking charges. ``If I knew that, why both of us would be a lot smarter,'' Bush told reporters after the Pentagon sessions. Just a few hours later, Thurman announced in Panama City that Noriega was at the Papal Nunciate there and was seeking asylum. Bush, through White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, announced a few minutes later, ``I am pleased that the general is now under the control of diplomatic authorities. His reign of terror is over.'' It was not immediately clear whether the U.S. government would be able to bring him to the United States to stand trial. The Italian news agency ANSA quoted the papal nuncio in Panama City, Monignor Sebastiano Laboa, as indicating he would not hand over Noriega to the United States or U.S.-installed government in Panama. After the Pentagon sessions earlier Sunday, Bush told reporters outside the Pentagon that ``the emphasis now is on cleaning up the last parts of resistance, seeing that civilian government take over, (restoring) tranquility in the city and then moving on food and medicine.'' Noting the holiday, Bush said he wanted to express ``my gratitude to the fine military officers and men who are taking part in this operation. It's been outstanding.'' ``I must say that the military, having fulfilled a major objective _ knocking out the Panamanian Defense Forces almost entirely _ is now putting a great deal of proper emphasis on humanitarian concerns,'' he said. Bush said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was on his way to Panama, where the president said a ``real turnaround'' had occurred in restoring order. ``It's a very good pre-Christmas report that I have received,'' Bush said after his briefing by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and national security advisor Scowcroft. Bush also commented briefly on the tumult in Romania, saying he had just spoken to the U.S. ambassador in Bucharest. He called the events there ``a very traumatic pre-Christmas uprising'' but said it appeared that pro-democracy forces, which include the nation's army, appeared to be gaining ground. He said the Romanian military had gained ``a little more control'' of the country in fighting with remnants of the secret police, who remain loyal to deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. While at the Pentagon, Bush taped a radio message to U.S. troops around the globe, offering a ``special salute'' to those in Panama and a tribute to U.S. servicemen who died in the fighting there. ``In Panama, as in every other such test in our history, Americans put their lives on the line for the basic values of liberty and decency on which our nation is founded,'' he said. ``Our hearts and those of every American go out to the families of those who fell. To all those who mourn a husband, a son, a brother, a father or a friend, I can only offer the thanks of a grateful nation. Your loved ones served a noble and just cause with honor and distinction.''
